Please check ‘Billing & plans’ section settings. Pro account, upon reviewing ‘Billing & plans’ section, indications failed payments exceeded spending limits. possible link ptds2024 organization account? apologize inconvenience advance hope won’t affect evaluation project.

title: What the Package Does (Title Case)
text: bpartyKIRDOL custom R package provides tools calculating radius based height cone. Additionally, includes Shiny application displays 5-day weather forecast three cities simultaneously simulates required volume ice cream surface area ice cream coating needed party.

title: What the Package Does (Title Case)
text: Functions compute radius per height cone: cone_radius_non_vectorized: Calculate radius cone based height. cone_radius_map: Calculate radius cone based height using map function. cone_radius_for: Calculate radius cone based height using forloops. cone_radius_sapply: Calculate radius cone based height using sapply function. cone_radius_vectorized: Calculate radius cone based height using Vectorize function. cone_radius_vectorized_direct: Calculate radius cone based height using vectorized operations. functions: calculate_cone_metrics: Calculate volume surface area cone based height. Utilize cone_radius_vectorized_direct function calculate radius height. apply slight random variation radius. get_average_metrics_for_day: Use OpenWeather.org “5 day weather forecast” gets forecast next 5 days. gives average temperature, pressure humidity given day list. Shiny application: run_ice_cream_party_planner: Run Shiny application simulates required volume ice cream surface area ice cream coating needed party. also displays 5-day weather forecast three cities simultaneously.

title: What the Package Does (Title Case)
text: Since package published CRAN public repository, need clone repository install manually. Clone Repository using GitHub Desktop using commands terminal Open project RStudio Install package clicking “Clean Install” Build tab dropdown menu top right corner RStudio can use package want Running tests: run tests, can run devtools::test() console. run tests show results. can also click Test button Build tab RStudio.

title: What the Package Does (Title Case)
text: package depends following packages: httr (API calls) jsonlite (JSON parsing) stats (mathematical functions) shiny (Shiny application) ggplot2 (plotting) shinythemes (Shiny application theme) (file paths) parallel (parallel processing) purrr (functional programming) following packages use testing, website R-CMD-check: testthat (testing) usethis (package development) pkgdown (website)

title: What the Package Does (Title Case)
text: app ask API key OpenWeather.org. can get free API key signing website.

what: Variable radius function for a cone — cone_radius_vectorized_direct
title: Variable radius function for a cone — cone_radius_vectorized_direct
text: function computes radius cone various heights (`x_vals`) using piecewise formula. formula defines three distinct regions specific calculations radius, ensuring smooth transitions .

title: Variable radius function for a cone — cone_radius_vectorized_direct
Variable radius function for a cone — cone_radius_vectorized_direct
text: x_vals Numeric vector. sequence heights radius calculated.

title: Variable radius function for a cone — cone_radius_vectorized_direct
text: numeric vector length `x_vals`, element represents radius corresponding height.

title: Variable radius function for a cone — cone_radius_vectorized_direct
text: radius determined follows: 0 <= x_vals < 8: Radius calculated x_vals / 8. 8 <= x_vals < 8 + pi/2: Radius 1 + 1.5 * sin(x_vals - 8). x_vals >= 8 + pi/2: Radius 2.5 - 2 * cos(x_vals - 8).

title: Variable radius function for a cone — cone_radius_vectorized_direct
text: Lodrik Adam

title: Variable radius function for a cone — cone_radius_vectorized_direct
code: # Radius at height 4.5 cone_radius_vectorized_direct(4.5) #> [1] 0.5625 # Generate a sequence of heights heights <- seq(0, 12, length.out = 100) # Compute the radius at each height radii <- cone_radius_vectorized_direct(heights) # Inspect the results head(radii) #> [1] 0.00000000 0.01515152 0.03030303 0.04545455 0.06060606 0.07575758

what: Get average temperature, humidity, and pressure for a city on a specific day — get_average_metrics_for_day
title: Get average temperature, humidity, and pressure for a city on a specific day — get_average_metrics_for_day
text: function retrieves weather forecast data given city using OpenWeatherMap API calculates average temperature (Celsius), humidity (fraction), pressure (hPa) specified day forecast.

title: Get average temperature, humidity, and pressure for a city on a specific day — get_average_metrics_for_day
Get average temperature, humidity, and pressure for a city on a specific day — get_average_metrics_for_day
text: city_name Character. name city retrieve weather forecast. api_key Character. OpenWeatherMap API key. day_number Integer. day forecast retrieve, 1 corresponds first day forecast. vary 1 5.

title: Get average temperature, humidity, and pressure for a city on a specific day — get_average_metrics_for_day
text: function returns list following components: temperature: Numeric. average temperature specified day (Celsius). humidity: Numeric. average humidity specified day (fraction, e.g., 0.5 50 pressure: Numeric. average pressure specified day (hPa).

title: Get average temperature, humidity, and pressure for a city on a specific day — get_average_metrics_for_day
text: function retrieves 5-day forecast OpenWeatherMap API, filters forecast data specified day, calculates average temperature, humidity, pressure. temperature converted Kelvin Celsius, humidity converted fraction convenience.

title: Get average temperature, humidity, and pressure for a city on a specific day — get_average_metrics_for_day
text: Lodrik Adam

title: Get average temperature, humidity, and pressure for a city on a specific day — get_average_metrics_for_day
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example usage: city <- "London" api_key <- "your_api_key_here" day <- 2  # Get the average metrics for the second day in the forecast metrics <- get_average_metrics_for_day(city_name = city, api_key = api_key, day_number = day) print(metrics) } # }

what: Launch the Ice Cream Party Planner Shiny Application — run_ice_cream_party_planner
title: Launch the Ice Cream Party Planner Shiny Application — run_ice_cream_party_planner
text: function initializes runs Shiny application analyzing climate factors simulating ice cream cone requirements based weather forecasts. Upon launching, users prompted enter OpenWeatherMap API key. application allows users input city name, select date, choose weather parameters display, view forecast data alongside simulation results ice cream volume surface area 3 cities simultaneously. Ensure valid OpenWeatherMap API key launching application. application utilizes parallel processing enhance simulation performance.

title: Launch the Ice Cream Party Planner Shiny Application — run_ice_cream_party_planner
Launch the Ice Cream Party Planner Shiny Application — run_ice_cream_party_planner
text: Lauches Shiny application analyzing climate factors simulating ice cream cone requirements. app provides following features: API Key Input: Securely enter store OpenWeatherMap API key. City Modules: Three separate modules analyze different cities simultaneously. Weather Forecast: View 5-day forecasts temperature, humidity, pressure. Simulations: Run simulations determine ice cream cone requirements based selected weather metrics. Visualizations: Interactive plots histograms visualize forecast data simulation outcomes.

title: Launch the Ice Cream Party Planner Shiny Application — run_ice_cream_party_planner
text: Lodrik Adam
